thread.title: Report: Hot dog contents include human DNA, mystery meat
thread.title_full: Report: Hot dog contents include human DNA, mystery meat - FOX 8 WVUE New Orleans News, Weather, Sports, Social

author: Kimberly Wright
title: Report: Hot dog contents include human DNA, mystery meat
text:
(RNN) - Some brands of hot dogs may have questionable pedigrees.
According to a report from Clear Food , an organization that evaluates foods on the molecular level, 14.4 percent of the 345 sampled hot dogs and sausages had issues, including substitutions not listed on the packaging and hygiene issues.
"Hygienic issues occur when some sort of non-harmful contaminant is introduced to the hot dog, in most cases, human DNA," Clear Food stated.
Substitutions included unlabeled meats, as well as meats in 10 percent of the vegetarian hot dogs sampled.
Human DNA was found in 2 percent of samples and 2/3 of vegetarian hot dogs tested.
Chicken was listed as the top mystery meat, found in 10 samples, followed by beef, pork, turkey and lamb.
Hot dog labels exaggerated the amount of protein "by as much as 2.5 times."
Despite the bad report, Clear Food listed the top 10 brands of hot dogs , which had the highest score, "a representation of how closely a product's label claims match its actual molecular contents. The higher the score, the more closely a product abides by its claims."
Clear Food listed Butterball, McCormick, Echrick and Hebrew National among the top-rated brands.
No matter how you serve it - slaw, sauerkraut, mustard, relish or chili - the hot dog remains a staple of the American culinary experience.
People in the U.S. spent $2.5 billion on hot dogs in supermarkets last year, according to the National Hot Dog and Sausage Council .
